div.head: A SPEECH Delivered by the Earle OF MANCHESTER.

opener.salute: MY Lord Major and Gentlemen you of the City of London,

div.p:
this AÅ¿Å¿embly can never bee looked upon by any Members of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament; but there muÅ¿t bee Å¿ome offering of gratitude made to you, both of thankes and acknowledgments for your former large-hearted expreÅ¿Å¿ions, both of affection and care for the preÅ¿ervation both of the Parliament and Kingdome: The occaÅ¿ion why my Lords, and theÅ¿e Gentlemen of the HouÅ¿e of Commons are come hither is this, They have read an AnÅ¿wer to an humble Petition of the Lord Major and Common-counÅ¿ell and Citizens of London to His MajeÅ¿ty;
In which AnÅ¿wer, They finde many wounding aÅ¿perÅ¿ions caÅ¿t upon perÅ¿ons of very eminent Authority in your City, and upon others of very great fidelity and truÅ¿t among you; this AnÅ¿wer they doe finde as it is printed to agree with that which the Gentleman from His MajeÅ¿tie hath here read; And they owning themÅ¿elves equally intereÅ¿Å¿ed (in all things that concerne you) with you, have commanded this Gentleman to make Å¿ome obÅ¿ervations by way of vindication both of the proceedings of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament, and of the proceedings of the City, with this aÅ¿Å¿urance that they will never diÅ¿Å¿ert you, but will Å¿tand by you with their lives and fortunes for the preÅ¿ervation of the City in generall, and thoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons in particular, who have beene faithfull, and deÅ¿erved well, both of the Parliament and Kingdome, and they will purÅ¿ue all meanes both with their lives and fortunes, that may be for the preÅ¿ervation of this City, and for the procuring of Å¿afety, happineÅ¿Å¿e, and peace to the whole Kingdome.

The Speech of this Noble Lord, being entertained with loud expreÅ¿sions of joy and thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e by the Commons; and after Å¿ome time of Å¿ilence being made, Mr. Pym that worthy Member of the HouÅ¿e of Commons and Patriot of his Countrey, gave the Å¿enÅ¿e of both HouÅ¿es upon the Å¿everall paÅ¿Å¿ages of His MajeÅ¿ties AnÅ¿wer; expreÅ¿sing it in the next Page following.

div.head: A SPEECH DELIVERED BY JOHN PYM EÅ¿quire.

opener.salute: MY Lord Major, and you worthy Citizens of this noble and famous City of London,

div.p:
I am commanded by the Lords and Commons, to let you know, that in this AnÅ¿wer, which hath beene publiÅ¿hed to you, they doe obÅ¿erve many things of great aÅ¿perÅ¿ion upon the proceedings of Parliament very Å¿candalous and injurious to many particular Members of this City, whereupon they thinke that it becomes them, both in tenderneÅ¿Å¿e of their owne honour, and reÅ¿pect to you, to take away all thoÅ¿e aÅ¿perÅ¿ions, and to let you know the truth of their proceedings, which have beene full of honour and juÅ¿tice, as they Å¿tand in relation to their owne duty, and full of humility, and obedience towards His MajeÅ¿ty, and of care for the common good, and Å¿o Å¿hall ever be; And they have commanded me to let you know the true AnÅ¿wer to moÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e things that are imputed either to the Parliament, or to the City, by obÅ¿erving Å¿ome particulars of This booke which hath beene read to
you and to let you know the proceedings in their owne native condition, cleere from thoÅ¿e miÅ¿repreÅ¿entations which make them appeare in a qualitie much different from the truth: which before I enter into I am to declare as the SenÅ¿e of both HouÅ¿es that your petition was Å¿o full of Loyaltie, Humilitie, and Obedience, that you might well have expected an AnÅ¿wer of another kinde.

The firÅ¿t ObÅ¿ervation I am to make to you is this, that it is Å¿aid here, That His MajeÅ¿ty was enforc'd by tumults to leave the Parliament, and to goe from White-hall, and to withdraw himÅ¿elfe into thoÅ¿e courÅ¿es, which now he hath taken.

In AnÅ¿wer hereunto, I am commanded to tell you, that there was no occaÅ¿ion given by any tumults riÅ¿ing out of this City or the Suburbs which might juÅ¿tly cauÅ¿e His MajeÅ¿ties departure, and you may very well remember, that after His violent comming to the Commons HouÅ¿e of Parliament in that unuÅ¿uall and unheard of manner (which was the beginning of theÅ¿e unhappy differences) that the very next day His MajeÅ¿ty came into the City without any Guard, that He was preÅ¿ent in the Common-councell, din'd at the Sheriffes, and returned back againe, with manifold evidences of fidelity on the part of the City, and without any Å¿uch expreÅ¿Å¿ions as were unbeÅ¿eeming the MajeÅ¿ty of a King, or the duty of Subjects; that He reÅ¿ided divers dayes at White-hall, and afterward at Hampton-court, WindÅ¿or, and places adjoyning, with Å¿mall Forces about him, and yet never any attempt made which might give Him any apprehenÅ¿ions of feare; by all which it is manifeÅ¿t, that this is an unjuÅ¿t aÅ¿perÅ¿ion caÅ¿t upon this City, that any tumultuous carriage of yours, was your occaÅ¿ion of His MajeÅ¿ties leaving the Parliament and withdrawing himÅ¿elfe to remoter parts.

It is affirmed, that the Government of your City hath been mannaged by a few deÅ¿perate perÅ¿ons, and that they do exerciÅ¿e an arbitrary power.] In anÅ¿wer to which the two HouÅ¿es of Parliament gives you this teÅ¿timony, that you have in moÅ¿t of the great occaÅ¿ions concerning the Government of the City, followed their direction, and that direction which they have given, and you have executed, they muÅ¿t & will maintain to be Å¿uch as Å¿tands with their honor in giving it, and your truÅ¿t and fidelity in the performance of it.

It is objected in the third place; That Contributions have been publickly made, for the maintenance of that Army which did joyne Battell with the King, and did by all the means that TreaÅ¿on and Malice could Å¿uggest, endeavour to take away His Life, and deÅ¿troy His IÅ¿Å¿ue.] To this I am commanded to Å¿ay, That the deÅ¿ign of bringing up the EngliÅ¿h Armies, the gathering together of the Cavaliers about White-hall, the violent coming to the HouÅ¿e of Commons, the Kings going into the North, and raiÅ¿ing Armes there, are cleer evidences that violence was firÅ¿t intended, and divers practiÅ¿es were made againÅ¿t the Parliament, before they took any courÅ¿e, or made any preparation to take up arms for their defence; for the danger of His MajeÅ¿ties perÅ¿on they were Å¿orry for it, and did by divers humble Petitions labour to prevent it; And as touching the royall iÅ¿Å¿ue, they have Å¿ufficiently declar'd to the world, their good affections towards them, by the care they have taken both for the Å¿afety and maintenance of thoÅ¿e who are left here.

It is further expreÅ¿Å¿'d in this AnÅ¿wer; That the King demands the Lord Major, MaÅ¿ter Alderman Fowke, Colonell Ven, and Colonell Manwaring, to be delivered up as guilty of SchiÅ¿me and high TreaÅ¿on.] Concerning
which, I am commanded to tell you, as the Å¿enÅ¿e of both HouÅ¿es of PARLIAMENT, That this demand is againÅ¿t the priviledge of Parliament (two of them being Members of the Commons HouÅ¿e) moÅ¿t diÅ¿hhonorable to the City, That the Lord Major of London Å¿hould be Å¿ubjected to the violence of every baÅ¿e fellow, be aÅ¿Å¿aulted, Å¿eiz'd on, without due proceÅ¿Å¿e or Warrant, which the Law doth afford every private man; and that you Å¿hould be commanded to deliver up your chief MagiÅ¿trates, and Å¿uch eminent Members of the City to the Kings pleaÅ¿ure, only becauÅ¿e they have done their duty in adhering to the Parliament, for the defence of the Kingdom, and that it is againÅ¿t the rules of juÅ¿tice, that any men Å¿hould be impriÅ¿oned upon Å¿uch a generall charge, when no particulars are proved againÅ¿t them; and this you are to take notice of, as the anÅ¿wer to thoÅ¿e Å¿candalls, and to that diÅ¿grace upon my Lord Major, and the other Members of the City.

And I am further to tell you, that there is little cauÅ¿e for His MajeÅ¿ty to make this demand, conÅ¿idering that He HimÅ¿elf doth by force keep away many accuÅ¿ed in Parliament, as my Lord Digby, and many more impeached of high TreaÅ¿on, beÅ¿ides divers others great Delinquents, that Å¿tand charged there for hainous crimes, all which by force are kept from the due proceedings, and legall triall in Parliament.

It is alleaged in this AnÅ¿wer, That my Lord Maior, and thoÅ¿e other perÅ¿ons named, are countenancers of BrowniÅ¿ts, and AnabaptiÅ¿ts, and all manner of Sectaries.] To this I am commanded to Å¿ay, That hereof there is no proof; It doth not appear that they give any Å¿uch countenance to Sectaries of any kinde whatÅ¿oever; and if it did, His MajeÅ¿ty hath little reaÅ¿on to object it, while notwithÅ¿tanding
the profeÅ¿Å¿ion he hath often made, that he will maintain the ProteÅ¿tant reformed Religion, he doth in the mean time raiÅ¿e an Army of PapiÅ¿ts, who by the principles of their Religion are bound, (if power be put into their hands) to deÅ¿troy and utterly to root out the ProteÅ¿tants together with the truth which they profeÅ¿Å¿e.

It is affirmed, That mens perÅ¿ons have been impriÅ¿oned, and their houÅ¿es plunder'd, becauÅ¿e they will not rebell againÅ¿t His MajeÅ¿ty.] To this I am commanded to declare, that no mens houÅ¿es have been plunder'd by any direction of the Parliament, but that they have been very carefull to reÅ¿train all Å¿uch violent courÅ¿es, Å¿o far as they were able; and that they have never committed any man, but Å¿uch men as by due information they conceived to be Å¿editious perÅ¿ons, and like to trouble the peace of the State.

It is objected further; That the Property of the Subject is deÅ¿troyed by taking away the twentieth part by an Arbitrary power.] To this they Å¿ay, That that Ordinance it doth not require a twentieth part, but doth limit the AÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors, that they Å¿hall not go beyond a twentieth part; and that this is done by a power derived from both houÅ¿es of Parliament; the Lords who have an hereditarie intereÅ¿t in making Laws in this Kingdom, and the Commons who are elected and choÅ¿en to repreÅ¿ent the whole body of the Comminalty, and truÅ¿ted for the good of the people, when ever they Å¿ee cauÅ¿e to charge the Kingdom: And they Å¿ay further, that the Å¿ame Law that did enable the two HouÅ¿es of Parliament to raiÅ¿e forces to maintain and defend the Å¿afety of Religion, and of the Kingdom, doth likewiÅ¿e enable them to require contributions, whereby thoÅ¿e forces may be maintained, or elÅ¿e it were a vaine power to raiÅ¿e forces, if they had not a power likewiÅ¿e to maintain them in that Å¿ervice for which they were raiÅ¿ed.

And to this point I am commanded to adde this further anÅ¿wer, that there was little reaÅ¿on for this to be objected on his MajeÅ¿ties behalf, when it is well known that from the Å¿ubjects (which are within the power of his army) His MajeÅ¿ty doth take the full yeerly value of their Lands, and in Å¿ome caÅ¿es more that not only particular houÅ¿es, but whole Towns have been plunder'd by command and deÅ¿ign; and that by Proclamations men are declared to forfeit all their eÅ¿tates, becauÅ¿e they will not obey Arbitrary Commands, and this is commonly practiÅ¿ed by His MajeÅ¿ty, and on his part, and therefore there was little reaÅ¿on to charge the Parliament with Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary and moderate a contribution as the twentieth part.

It is declared, That the King expects to be kept from Tumults and Affronts.] Upon which, I am commanded to obÅ¿erve, that His MajeÅ¿ties expreÅ¿Å¿ions in His AnÅ¿wer tend to the making of a diviÅ¿ion in this City, and to the raiÅ¿ing of a party, which may make Å¿ome diÅ¿turbance in that orderly government which is now eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed, both which will certainly prove equally deÅ¿tructive to him and both HouÅ¿es of Parliament; and more prejudiciall to his quiet abode here, then any thing that hath ever beene acted by the HouÅ¿es of Parliament, or the preÅ¿ent Governors of the City.

They obÅ¿erve further that in this AnÅ¿wer, His MajeÅ¿ty doth profeÅ¿Å¿e that He will Å¿eize upon the eÅ¿tates of thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall contribute any thing towards the maintenance of the Parliaments Army, and will put them out of His protection, and by His MiniÅ¿ters in forraign States, will take Å¿uch courÅ¿e, that they may be proceeded againÅ¿t as enemies; that is, deÅ¿troyed and Å¿poiled.] To which the LORDS and COMMONS do Declare, That this is an exceÅ¿Å¿e of rigour and injuÅ¿tice
beyond all example, that particular men Å¿hould loÅ¿e their private eÅ¿tates here without law or judiciall proceeding: And that our Prince who owes protection to the Kingdom, aÅ¿well as to particular perÅ¿ons, Å¿hould Å¿uffer the wealth thereof to be robbed and Å¿poiled by forraign States; upon due conÅ¿ideration whereof, they hope His MajeÅ¿ty will be induced by better Councell to forbeare the execution, then that by which he hath been perÅ¿waded to publiÅ¿h Å¿uch a ReÅ¿olution.

BeÅ¿ides theÅ¿e ObÅ¿ervations out of the AnÅ¿wer, I am to obÅ¿erve one out of a narrative that was received from the Common Councell, that the King did Declare that he would Å¿end Å¿ome meÅ¿Å¿engers here to obÅ¿erve your carriage in the City, and what was done amongÅ¿t you, the Parliament have juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to doubt, that theÅ¿e will be meÅ¿Å¿engers of Å¿edition and trouble, and therefore deÅ¿ire you to obÅ¿erve them and find them out, and that they may know who they are.

At the end of every period of this Speech, the applauÅ¿e was Å¿o great, that he was fain to reÅ¿t till Å¿ilence was again made; and at laÅ¿t (the Company ready to be diÅ¿Å¿olved) after Å¿ome pauÅ¿e and conÅ¿ultation with the Committee of Lords and Commons then preÅ¿ent, and by their direction (Å¿ilence being made) he cloÅ¿ed all with the words following:

p.q: Worthy Citizens, you have underÅ¿tood the Å¿enÅ¿e of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament, concerning my Lord Major here, and thoÅ¿e worthy Members of your City, that are demanded; you have heard the Parliament declare, that they will protect them in that which they have done by direction of both HouÅ¿es; and they expect that you Å¿hould expreÅ¿Å¿e it your Å¿elves likewiÅ¿e, that if any violence be offer'd to them, you will Å¿ecure and defend them with your uttermoÅ¿t force; and you Å¿hall alwaies finde, that this protection of the Parliament Å¿hall not onely extend to theÅ¿e, but to all others that have done any thing by their command.

div.p: Which words were no Å¿ooner uttered, but the Citizens with one joynt harmony of mindes and voices, gave Å¿uch an acclamation as would have drown'd all the former, if they had been then breathing, which after a long continuance reÅ¿olv'd it Å¿elf into this more articulate and diÅ¿tinct voice, We will live and dye with them, We will live and dye with them, and the like.
